title: This is the Queen's favourite breakfast cereal
text:
This is the Queen's favourite breakfast cereal And she likes something interesting in her mushrooms Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
The Queen may eat like a king, but she's actually partial to a modest bowl of cereal in the morning. 
Much has been written about the Queen's royal banqueting, her trip to Waitrose, and her expensive dining. 
Her Majesty drinks plenty of champagne . She has a glass in the evening. When she pleases, she nibble on prime Scottish venison from Balmoral, and white peaches from Windsor Castle. Her carrots are cut to a certain length. 
But in the morning, after some tea and biscuits, the Queen usually settles down to a bowl of Special K . That's her favourite. With whole milk, of course. The Queen would not rather have a bowl of Coco Pops Read More This is how much the Queen spent on food and drink last year 
Darren McGrady, former personal chef to the monarch, revealed in 2015 that the Queen enjoys the Kellogg's crunchy cereal and a piece or two of fruit for breakfast. Kellogg's, Quaker Oats, and Weetabix all hold royal warrants . She likes her cereal kept in Tupperware for freshness. 
She does vary her routine occasionally, however. 
Darren added: “The Queen loved scrambled eggs with smoked salmon and a grating of truffle. 
"But she was too frugal to ever order fresh truffles and only really enjoyed them at Christmas when the truffles were sent as a gift.” Special Q? (Photo: REUTERS) You'll never see the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge holding hands in public - here's why 
Occasionally, the royal enjoys toast and marmalade. She gets her preserves from Wilkins & Sons , and drinks Twinings English Breakfast tea. 
Apparently, despite often lavish meals full of smoked salmon and fine wines, Darren mentioned the Queen "eats to live," and isn't actually what you might describe as a "foodie". 
Her mushrooms, however, don't really reflect the sentiments above. She's been known to have them with Marmite – a fine combination. 
“When we cooked the Queen’s mushrooms we always added a smidgen of Marmite," said former palace chef Owen Hodgson. Like us on Facebook
